section.p: For a given WebClient, the focus can be on at most one element at any given time. Focus doesn't have to be on any element within the WebClient.

There are several ways to move the focus from one element to another. The simplest is to call com.gargoylesoftware.htmlunit.WebClient#moveFocusToElement(com.gargoylesoftware.htmlunit.html.HtmlElement). This method will remove focus from whatever element currently has it, if any, and will set it to the new component. Along the way, it will fire off any "onfocus" and "onblur" handlers that have been defined.
The element currently owning the focus can be determined with a call to com.gargoylesoftware.htmlunit.WebClient#getElementWithFocus()

To simulate keyboard navigation via the tab key, you can call com.gargoylesoftware.htmlunit.html.HtmlPage#tabToNextElement() and com.gargoylesoftware.htmlunit.html.HtmlPage#tabToPreviousElement() to cycle forward or backwards through the defined tab order. This tab order is defined by the tabindex attribute on the various elements as defined by the HTML specification. You can query the defined tab order with the method com.gargoylesoftware.htmlunit.html.HtmlPage.getTabbableElements() which will return a list of all tabbable elements in defined tab order.
Access keys, often called keyboard mnemonics, can be simulated with the method com.gargoylesoftware.htmlunit.html.HtmlPage#pressAccessKey(char).

Finally, there is an assertion for testing that will verify that every tabbable element has a defined tabindex attribute. This is done with com.gargoylesoftware.htmlunit.html.HtmlPage#assertAllTabIndexAttributesSet().
